Jonathon Chow

2024-06-09

Source: vignettes/SPA.Rmd
SPA.Rmd

Comparison of SPA Between Logistic Regression and NB GLM

Logistic regression model: \[Y_i\sim\mathbf{Bern}(\mu_i),\,\text{logit}(\mu_i)=\gamma G_i+\beta^{\top}X_i.\]

The goal is to test the null hypothesis \(H_0:\,\gamma=0\). Under the null hypothesis, the fitted model obtains the estimated parameters \(\hat{\mu}_i\).

A score statistic for \(gamma\) from the model is given by \[\begin{aligned} S&=G^{\top}(Y-\hat{\mu})\\ &=(G-X(X^{\top}WX)^{-1}X^{\top}WG)^{\top}(Y-\hat{\mu})\\ &=\sum_{i=1}^n \tilde{G}_i(Y_i-\hat{\mu}_i), \end{aligned}\] where \[W=\text{diag}(\cdots,\hat{\mu}_i(1-\hat{\mu}_i),\cdots),\] \[\tilde{G}=G-X(X^{\top}WX)^{-1}X^{\top}WG.\]

The traditional score test approximates the null distribution using a normal distribution \[\mathbf{N}(0,G^{\top}WG-G^{\top}WX(X^{\top}WX)^{-1}X^{\top}WG).\]

The saddlepoint approximation uses the cumulant-generating fuction of the score statistic \(S\) and its first- and second-order derivatives: \[K(t)=\sum_{i=1}^n\log\left(1-\hat{\mu}_i+\hat{\mu}_ie^{\tilde{G}_it}\right)-t\sum_{i=1}^n\tilde{G}_i\hat{\mu}_i,\] \[K^{\prime}(t)=\sum_{i=1}^n\frac{\hat{\mu}_i\tilde{G}_i}{(1-\hat{\mu}_i)e^{-\tilde{G}_it}+\hat{\mu}_i}-\sum_{i=1}^n\tilde{G}_i\hat{\mu}_i,\] \[K^{\prime\prime}(t)=\sum_{i=1}^n\frac{(1-\hat{\mu}_i)\hat{\mu}_i\tilde{G}_i^2e^{-\tilde{G}_it}}{\left[(1-\hat{\mu}_i)e^{-\tilde{G}_it}+\hat{\mu}_i\right]^2}.\]

The distribution of \(S\) at \(s\) is \[\Pr(S<s)=\Phi\left\{w+\frac{1}{w}\log\left(\frac{v}{w}\right)\right\},\] where \(w=sgn(\hat{t})\sqrt{2(\hat{t}s-K(\hat{t}))}\), \(v=\hat{t}\sqrt{k^{\prime\prime}(\hat{t})}\), \(\hat{t}\) is the solution to the equation \(K^{\prime}(t)=0\), and \(\Phi\) is the distribution function of a standard normal distribution.

 

NB generalized linear model:

\[Y_i\sim\mathbf{NB}_{\theta}(\mu_i),\,\log(\mu_i)=\gamma X_i+\beta^{\top}Z_i.\]

The goal is to test the null hypothesis \(H_0:\,\gamma=0\). Under the null hypothesis, the fitted model obtains the estimated parameters \(\hat{\mu}_i\) and \(\hat{\theta}\).

A score statistic for \(gamma\) from the model is given by \[\begin{aligned} S&=X^{\top}WM(Y-\hat{\mu})\\ &=\sum_{i=1}^n X_i\frac{\hat{\mu}_i}{1+\frac{\hat{\mu}_i}{\hat{\theta}}}\frac{1}{\hat{\mu}_i}(Y_i-\hat{\mu}_i)\\ &=\sum_{i=1}^n X_ip_i(Y_i-\hat{\mu}_i), \end{aligned}\] where \[W=\text{diag}\left(\cdots,\frac{\hat{\mu}_i}{1+\frac{\hat{\mu}_i}{\hat{\theta}}},\cdots\right),\] \[M=\text{diag}\left(\cdots,\frac{1}{\hat{\mu}_i},\cdots\right),\] \[p_i=\frac{\hat{\theta}}{\hat{\theta}+\hat{\mu}_i}.\]

The traditional score test approximates the null distribution using a normal distribution \[\mathbf{N}(0,X^{\top}WX-X^{\top}WZ(Z^{\top}WZ)^{-1}Z^{\top}WX).\]

The saddlepoint approximation uses the cumulant-generating fuction of the score statistic \(S\) and its first- and second-order derivatives: \[K(t)=\hat{\theta}\sum_{i=1}^n\log\left(\frac{p_i}{1-(1-p_i)e^{X_ip_it}}\right)-t\sum_{i=1}^nX_i\hat{\mu}_ip_i,\] \[K^{\prime}(t)=\hat{\theta}\sum_{i=1}^n\frac{(1-p_i)e^{X_ip_it}X_ip_i}{1-(1-p_i)e^{X_ip_it}}-\sum_{i=1}^nX_i\hat{\mu}_ip_i,\] \[K^{\prime\prime}(t)=\hat{\theta}\sum_{i=1}^n\frac{(1-p_i)e^{X_ip_it}X_i^2p_i^2}{\left[1-(1-p_i)e^{X_ip_it}\right]^2}.\]

The distribution of \(S\) at \(s\) is \[\Pr(S<s)=\Phi\left\{w+\frac{1}{w}\log\left(\frac{v}{w}\right)\right\},\] where \(w=sgn(\hat{t})\sqrt{2(\hat{t}s-K(\hat{t}))}\), \(v=\hat{t}\sqrt{k^{\prime\prime}(\hat{t})}\), \(\hat{t}\) is the solution to the equation \(K^{\prime}(t)=0\), and \(\Phi\) is the distribution function of a standard normal distribution.
